title: Feasibility of a Personal Neuromorphic Emulation
content: The representation of intelligence is achieved by patterns of connections among neurons in brains and machines. Brains grow continuously, such that their patterns of connections develop through activity-dependent specification with the continuing ontogenesis of individual experience. The theory of active inference proposes that the developmental organization of sentient systems reflects general processes of informatic self-evidencing, through the minimization of free energy, that may be described in information terms that are not dependent on a specific physical substrate. At a certain level of complexity, self-evidencing of living (self-organizing) information systems becomes hierarchic and reentrant, such that effective consciousness emerges as the consequence of a good regulator. These principles imply that an adequate reconstruction of the computational dynamics of an individual human brain is possible with a sufficient neuromorphic emulation.
